And no oneÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s had more access to the inner workings of the phenomenon than Kirkpatrick, a senior tech writer at Fortune magazine. Written with the full cooperation of founder Mark Zuckerberg, the book follows the company from its genesis in a Harvard dorm room through its successes over Friendster and MySpace, the expansion of the user base, and ZuckerbergÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s refusal to sell. The author is at his best discussing the social implications of the site, from the changing notions of privacy to why and how people use FacebookÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½increasingly itÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s to come together around a common interest or cause (the eponymous Facebook Effect). Though significantly more informative, thoughtful, and credible than Ben MezrichÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s The Accidental Billionaires, it may be hamstrung by its late entry; the furor over Facebook has more or less subsided, and potential readers are more likely to be using the site than to be reading about its origins.
